pages.title: Ahlfors finiteness theorem
pages.text:
In the mathematical theory of [[Kleinian group]]s, the '''Ahlfors finiteness theorem''' describes the quotient of the domain of discontinuity by a finitely generated Kleinian group. The theorem was proved by {{harvs|txt|authorlink=Lars Ahlfors|first=Lars |last=Ahlfors|year1=1964|year2=1965}}, apart from a gap that was filled by {{harvtxt|Greenberg|1967}}.

The Ahlfors finiteness theorem  states that if Γ is a finitely-generated Kleinian group  with region of discontinuity Ω, then
Ω/Γ has a finite number of components, each of which is a compact Riemann surface with a finite number of points removed.

==Bers area inequality==

The '''Bers area inequality''' is a quantitative refinement of the Ahlfors finiteness theorem proved by {{harvs|first=Lipman|last=Bers|authorlink=Lipman Bers|txt|year=1967a}}. It states that if Γ is a non-elementary finitely-generated Kleinian group with ''N'' generators and with region of discontinuity Ω, then
:Area(Ω/Γ) ≤ 4π(''N'' − 1)
with equality only for [[Schottky group]]s. (The area is given by the Poincaré metric in each component.)
Moreover, if Ω<sub>1</sub> is an invariant component then
:Area(Ω/Γ) ≤ 2Area(Ω<sub>1</sub>/Γ)
with equality only for [[Fuchsian group]]s of the first kind (so in particular there can be at most two invariant components).

pages.title: Algebraic representation
pages.text:
{{Short description|Group representation via algebra automorphisms}}{{distinguish|algebra representation}}

In mathematics, an '''algebraic representation''' of a [[group (mathematics)|group]] ''G'' on a [[algebra over a field|''k''-algebra]] ''A'' is a [[linear representation]] <math>\pi: G \to GL(A)</math> such that, for each ''g'' in ''G'',  <math>\pi(g)</math> is an [[algebra automorphism]]. Equipped with such a representation, the algebra ''A'' is then called a '''''G''-algebra'''.

For example, if ''V'' is a linear representation of a group ''G'', then the [[tensor product of representations|representation put on]] the [[tensor algebra]] <math>T(A)</math> is an algebraic represention of ''G''.

If ''A'' is a commutative ''G''-algebra, then <math>\operatorname{Spec}(A)</math> is an [[affine scheme|affine]] [[group-scheme action|''G''-scheme]].

pages.title: Algebraic torus
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], an '''algebraic torus''' is a type of commutative affine [[algebraic group]].  These [[Group (mathematics)|groups]] were named by analogy with the theory of ''tori'' in [[Lie group]] theory (see [[Cartan subgroup]]).

Tori are of fundamental importance in the theory of algebraic groups and Lie groups and in the study of the geometric objects associated to them such as [[symmetric space]]s and [[Building (mathematics)|buildings]].

== Algebraic tori over fields ==

In most places we suppose that the base field is [[Perfect field|perfect]] (for example finite or characteristic zero). In general one has to use separable closures instead of algebraic closures.

=== Multiplicative group of a field ===
{{Main article | Multiplicative group}}

If <math>F</math> is a field then the ''multiplicative group'' over <math>F</math> is the algebraic group <math>\mathbf G_{\mathbf m}</math> such that for any field extension <math>E/F</math> the <math>E</math>-points are isomorphic to the group <math>E^\times</math>. To define it properly as an algebraic group one can take the affine variety defined by the equation <math>xy = 1</math> in the affine plane over <math>F</math> with coordinates <math>x, y</math>. The multiplication is then given by restricting the regular rational map <math>F^2 \times F^2 \to F^2</math> defined by <math>((x, y), (x',y')) \mapsto (xx', yy') </math> and the inverse is the restriction of the regular rational map <math>(x, y) \mapsto (y, x)</math>.

=== Definition ===

Let <math>F</math> be a field with algebraic closure <math>\overline F</math>. Then a ''<math>F</math>-torus'' is an algebraic group defined over <math>F</math> which is isomorphic over <math>\overline F</math> to a finite product of copies of the multiplicative group.

In other words, if <math>\mathbf T</math> is an <math>F</math>-group it is a torus if and only if <math>\mathbf T(\overline F) \cong (\overline F^\times)^r</math> for some <math>r \ge 1</math>. The basic terminology associated to tori is as follows.

*The integer <math>r</math> is called the ''rank'' or ''absolute rank'' of the torus <math>\mathrm T</math>.
*The torus is said to be ''split'' over a field extension <math>E/F</math> if <math>\mathbf T(E) \cong (E^\times)^r</math>. There is a unique minimal finite extension of <matH>F</math> over which <math>\mathbf T</math> is split, which is called the ''splitting field'' of <math>\mathbf T</math>.
*The ''<math>F</math>-rank'' of <math>\mathbf T</math> is the maximal rank of a split sub-torus of <math>\mathbf T</math>. A torus is split if and only if its <math>F</math>-rank equals its absolute rank.
*A torus is said to be ''anisotropic'' if its <matH>F</math>-rank is zero.

=== Isogenies ===

An [[isogeny]] between algebraic groups is a surjective morphism with finite kernel; two tori are said to be ''isogenous'' if there exists an isogeny from the first to the second. Isogenies between tori are particularly well-behaved: for any isogeny <math>\phi:\mathbf T \to \mathbf T'</math> there exists a "dual" isogeny <math>\psi: \mathbf T' \to \mathbf T</math> such that <math>\psi \circ \phi</math> is a power map. In particular being isogenous is an equivalence relation between tori.

=== Examples ===

Over any algebraically closed field there is up to isomorphism a unique torus of any given rank.

Over the field of real numbers <math>\mathbb R</math> there are exactly (up to isomorphism) two tori of rank 1:
*the split torus <math>\mathbb R^\times</math> ; 
*the compact form, which can be realised as the [[unitary group]] <math>\mathbf U(1)</math> or as the special [[orthogonal group]] <math>\mathrm{SO}(2)</math>. It is an anisotropic torus. As a Lie group, it is also isomorphic to the 1-[[Torus (mathematics)|torus]] <math>\mathbf T^1</math>, which explains the picture of diagonalisable algebraic groups as tori.
Any real torus is isogenous to a finite sum of those two; for example the real torus <math>\mathbb C^\times</math> is doubly covered by (but not isomorphic to) <math>\mathbb R^\times \times \mathbb T^1</math>. This gives an example of isogenous, non-isomorphic tori.

Over the [[finite field]] <math>\mathbb F_q</math> there are two rank-1 tori: the split one, of cardinality <math>q-1</math>, and the anisotropic one of cardinality <math>q+1</math>. The latter can be realised as the matrix group
:<math> \left\{ \begin{pmatrix} t & du \\ u & t \end{pmatrix} : t,u \in \mathbb F_q, t^2 - du^2=1 \right\} \subset \mathrm{SL}_2(\mathbb F_q) </math>.

More generally, if <math>E/F</math> is a finite field extension of degree <math>d</math> then the [[Weil restriction]] from <math>E</math> to <math>F</math> of the multiplicative group of <math>E</math> is an <math>F</math>-torus of rank <math>d</math> and <math>F</math>-rank 1 (note that restriction of scalars over an inseparable field extension will yield a commutative algebraic group that is not a torus). The kernel <math>N_{E/F}</math> of its [[field norm]] is also a torus, which is anisotropic and of rank <math>d-1</math>. Any <math>F</math>-torus of rank one is either split or isomorphic to the kernel of the norm of a quadratic extension.<ref>{{ cite book | ref=harv | title=Algebraic groups and their birational invariants | last=Voskresenskii | first=V. S. | series=Translations of mathematical monographs | publisher=American Math. Soc. | date=1998}}</ref> The two examples above are special cases of this: the compact real torus is the kernel of the field norm of <math>\mathbb C/\mathbb R</math> and the anisotropic torus over <math>\mathbb F_q</math> is the kernel of the field norm of <math>\mathbb F_{q^2} / \mathbb F_q</math>.

== Weights and coweights ==

Over a separably closed field, a torus ''T'' admits two primary invariants. The [[Weight (representation theory)|weight]] [[Lattice (group)|lattice]] <math>X^\bullet(T)</math> is the group of algebraic homomorphisms ''T'' → '''G'''<sub>m</sub>, and the coweight lattice <math>X_\bullet(T)</math> is the group of algebraic homomorphisms '''G'''<sub>m</sub> → ''T''.  These are both free abelian groups whose rank is that of the torus, and they have a canonical nondegenerate pairing <math>X^\bullet(T) \times X_\bullet(T) \to \mathbb{Z}</math> given by <math>(f,g) \mapsto \text{deg}(f \circ g)</math>, where degree is the number ''n'' such that the composition is equal to the ''n''th power map on the multiplicative group.  The functor given by taking weights is an antiequivalence of categories between tori and free abelian groups, and the coweight functor is an equivalence.  In particular, maps of tori are characterized by linear transformations on weights or coweights, and the automorphism group of a torus is a general linear group over '''Z'''.  The quasi-inverse of the weights functor is given by a dualization functor from free abelian groups to tori, defined by its functor of points as:

:<math>D(M)_S(X) := \mathrm{Hom}(M, \mathbb{G}_{m,S}(X)).</math>

This equivalence can be generalized to pass between groups of multiplicative type (a distinguished class of [[formal group]]s) and arbitrary abelian groups, and such a generalization can be convenient if one wants to work in a well-behaved category, since the category of tori doesn't have kernels or filtered colimits.

When a field ''K'' is not separably closed, the weight and coweight lattices of a torus over ''K'' are defined as the respective lattices over the separable closure.  This induces canonical continuous actions of the absolute Galois group of ''K'' on the lattices.  The weights and coweights that are fixed by this action are precisely the maps that are defined over ''K''.  The functor of taking weights is an antiequivalence between the category of tori over ''K'' with algebraic homomorphisms and the category of finitely generated torsion free abelian groups with an action of the absolute Galois group of ''K''.

Given a finite separable field extension ''L''/''K'' and a torus ''T'' over ''L'', we have a [[Galois module]] isomorphism

:<math>X^\bullet(\mathrm{Res}_{L/K}T) \cong \mathrm{Ind}_{G_L}^{G_K} X^\bullet(T).</math>

If ''T'' is the multiplicative group, then this gives the restriction of scalars a permutation module structure.  Tori whose weight lattices are permutation modules for the Galois group are called quasi-split, and all quasi-split tori are finite products of restrictions of scalars.

== Tori in semisimple groups ==

=== Linear representations of tori ===

As seen in the examples above tori can be represented as linear groups. An alternative definition for tori is:

:''A linear algebraic group is a torus if and only if it is diagonalisable over an algebraic closure. ''

The torus is split over a field if and only if it is diagonalisable over this field.

=== Split rank of a semisimple group ===

If <math>\mathbf G</math> is a semisimple algebraic group over a field <math>F</math> then:
*its ''rank'' (or ''absolute rank'') is the rank of a maximal torus subgroup in <math>\mathbf G</math> (note that all maximal tori are conjugated over <math>F</math> so the rank is well-defined); 
*its ''<math>F</math>-rank'' (sometimes called ''<math>F</math>-split rank'') is the maximal rank of a torus subgroup in <math>G</math> which is split over <math>F</math>. 
Obviously the rank is larger than the <math>F</math>-rank; the group is called ''split'' if and only if equality holds (that is, there is a maximal torus in <math>\mathbf G</math> which is split over <math>F</math>). The group is called ''anisotropic'' if it contains no split tori (i.e. its <math>F</math>-rank is zero).

=== Classification of semisimple groups ===
{{Main article|Tits index}}

In the classical theory of [[semisimple Lie algebra]]s over the complex field the [[Cartan subalgebra]]s play a fundamental rôle in the classification via [[root system]]s and [[Dynkin diagram]]s. This classification is equivalent to that of connected algebraic groups over the complex field, and Cartan subalgebras correspond to maximal tori in these. In fact the classification carries over to the case of an arbitrary base field under the assumption that there exists a split maximal torus (which is automatically satisfied over an algebraically closed field). Without the splitness assumption things become much more complicated and a more detailed theory has to be developed, which is still based in part on the study of adjoint actions of tori.

If <math>\mathbf T</math> is a maximal torus in a semisimple algebraic group <math>\mathbf G</math> then over the algebraic closure it gives rise to a root system <math>\Phi</math> in the vector space <math>V = X^*(\mathbf T) \otimes_{\mathbb Z} \mathbb R</math>. On the other hand, if <math>{}_F \mathbf T \subset \mathbf T</math> is a maximal <math>F</math>-split torus its action on the <math>F</math>-Lie algebra of <math>\mathbf G</math> gives rise to another root system <math>{}_F \Phi</math>. The restriction map <math>X^*(\mathbf T) \to X^*(_F\mathbf T)</math> induces a map <math>\Phi \to {}_F\Phi \cup\{0\}</math> and the [[Tits index]] is a way to encode the properties of this map and of the action of the Galois group of <math>\overline F / F</math> on <math>\Phi</math>. The Tits index is a "relative" version of the "absolute" Dynkin diagram associated to <math>\Phi</math>; obviously, only finitely many Tits indices can correspond to a given Dynkin diagram.

Another invariant associated to the split torus <math>{}_F \mathbf T</math> is the ''anisotropic kernel'': this is the semisimple algebraic group obtained as the derived subgroup of the centraliser of <math>{}_F \mathbf T</math> in <math>\mathbf G</math> (the latter is only a reductive group). As its name indicates it is an anisotropic group, and its absolute type is uniquely determined by <math>{}_F \Phi</math>.

The first step towards a classification is then the following theorem{{sfn|Tits|1966|loc=Theorem 2.7.1}}

:''Two semisimple <math>F</math>-algebraic groups are isomorphic if and only if they have the same Tits indices and isomorphic anisotropic kernels. ''

This reduces the classification problem to anisotropic groups, and to determining which Tits indices can occur for a given Dynkin diagram. The latter problem has been solved in {{harvtxt|Tits|1966}}. The former is related to the [[Galois cohomology]] groups of <math>F</math>. More precisely to each Tits index there is associated a unique [[quasi-split group]] over <math>F</math>; then every <math>F</math>-group with the same index is an [[inner form]] of this quasi-split group, and those are classified by the Galois cohomology of <math>F</math> with coefficients in the adjoint group.

== Tori and geometry ==

=== Flat subspaces and rank of symmetric spaces ===

If <math>G</math> is a semisimple Lie group then its '''real rank''' is the <math>\mathbb R</math>-rank as defined above (for any <math>\mathbb R</math>-algebraic group whose group of real points is isomorphic to <math>G</math>), in other words the maximal <math>r</math> such that there exists an embedding <math>(\mathbb R^\times)^r \to G</math>. For example, the real rank of <math>\mathrm{SL}_n(\mathbb R)</math> is equal to <math>n-1</math>, and the real rank of <math>\mathrm{SO}(p,q)</math> is equal to <math>\min(p,q)</math>.

If <math>X</math> is the [[symmetric space]] associated to <math>G</math> and <math>T \subset G</math> is a maximal split torus then there exists a unique orbit of <math>T</math> in <math>X</math> which is a totally geodesic flat subspace in <math>X</math>. It is in fact a maximal flat subspace and all maximal such are obtained as orbits of split tori in this way. Thus there is a geometric definition of the real rank, as the maximal dimension of a flat subspace in <math>X</math>.{{sfn|Witte-Morris|2015|p=22}}

=== Q-rank of lattices ===

If the Lie group <math>G</math> is obtained as the real points of an algebraic group <math>\mathbf G</math> over the rational field <math>\mathbb Q</math> then the <math>\mathbb Q</math>-rank of <math>\mathbf G</math> has also a geometric significance. To get to it one has to introduce an [[arithmetic group]] <math>\Gamma</math> associated to <matH>\mathbf G</math>, which roughly is the group of integer points of <math>\mathbf G</math>, and the quotient space <math>M = \Gamma \backslash X</math>, which is a Riemannian orbifold and hence a metric space. Then any [[asymptotic cone]] of <math>M</math> is homeomorphic to a finite [[simplicial complex]] with top-dimensional simplices of dimension equal to the <math>\mathbb Q</math>-rank of <math>\mathbf G</math>. In particular, <math>M</math> is compact if and only if <math>\mathbf G</math> is anisotropic.{{sfn|Witte-Morris|2015|p=25}}

Note that this allows to define the <math>\mathbf Q</math>-rank of any lattice in a semisimple Lie group, as the dimension of its asymptotic cone.

=== Buildings ===
{{Main article | Building (mathematics)}}

If <math>\mathbf G</math> is a semisimple group over <math>\mathbb Q_p</math> the maximal split tori in <math>\mathbf G</math> correspond to the apartments of the Bruhat-Tits building <math>X</math> associated to <math>\mathbf G</math>. In particular the dimension of <math>X</math> is equal to the <math>\mathbb Q_p</matH>-rank of <math>\mathbf G</math>.

== Algebraic tori over an arbitrary base scheme ==

=== Definition ===

Given a base [[Scheme (mathematics)|scheme]] ''S'', an algebraic torus over ''S'' is defined to be a [[group scheme]] over ''S'' that is [[flat topology|fpqc locally]] isomorphic to a finite product of copies of the multiplicative group scheme '''G'''<sub>''m''</sub>/''S'' over ''S''.  In other words, there exists a faithfully flat map ''X'' → ''S'' such that any point in ''X'' has a quasi-compact open neighborhood ''U'' whose image is an open affine subscheme of ''S'', such that base change to ''U'' yields a finite product of copies of ''GL''<sub>1,''U''</sub> = '''G'''<sub>''m''</sub>/''U''.{{clarify|reason=undefined notation|date=March 2015}}  One particularly important case is when ''S'' is the spectrum of a field ''K'', making a torus over ''S'' an algebraic group whose extension to some finite separable extension ''L'' is a finite product of copies of '''G'''<sub>''m''</sub>/''L''.  In general, the multiplicity of this product (i.e., the dimension of the scheme) is called the [[rank (differential topology)|rank]] of the torus, and it is a locally constant function on ''S''.

Most notions defined for tori over fields carry to this more general setting.

=== Weights ===

For a general base scheme ''S'', weights and coweights are defined as fpqc sheaves of free abelian groups on ''S''.  These provide representations of fundamental groupoids of the base with respect the fpqc topology.  If the torus is locally trivializable with respect to a weaker topology such as the etale topology, then the sheaves of groups descend to the same topologies and these representations factor through the respective quotient groupoids.  In particular, an etale sheaf gives rise to a quasi-isotrivial torus, and if ''S'' is locally noetherian and normal (more generally, [[Unibranch local ring|geometrically unibranched]]), the torus is isotrivial.  As a partial converse, a theorem of [[Grothendieck]] asserts that any torus of finite type is quasi-isotrivial, i.e., split by an etale surjection.

Given a rank ''n'' torus ''T'' over ''S'', a twisted form is a torus over ''S'' for which there exists a fpqc covering of ''S'' for which their base extensions are isomorphic, i.e., it is a torus of the same rank.  Isomorphism classes of twisted forms of a split torus are parametrized by nonabelian flat cohomology <math>H^1(S, GL_n(\mathbb{Z}))</math>, where the coefficient group forms a constant sheaf.  In particular, twisted forms of a split torus ''T'' over a field ''K'' are parametrized by elements of the Galois cohomology pointed set <math>H^1(G_K, GL_n(\mathbb{Z}))</math> with trivial Galois action on the coefficients.  In the one-dimensional case, the coefficients form a group of order two, and isomorphism classes of twisted forms of '''G'''<sub>m</sub> are in natural bijection with separable quadratic extensions of ''K''.

Since taking a weight lattice is an equivalence of categories, short exact sequences of tori correspond to short exact sequences of the corresponding weight lattices.  In particular, extensions of tori are classified by Ext<sup>1</sup> sheaves.  These are naturally isomorphic to the flat cohomology groups <math>H^1(S, \mathrm{Hom}_\mathbb{Z} (X^\bullet(T_1), X^\bullet(T_2)))</math>.  Over a field, the extensions are parametrized by elements of the corresponding Galois cohomology group.

==Arithmetic invariants==

In his work on [[Weil conjecture on Tamagawa numbers|Tamagawa numbers]], [[Takashi Ono (mathematician)|T. Ono]] introduced a type of functorial invariants of tori over finite separable extensions of a chosen field ''k''.  Such an invariant is a collection of positive real-valued functions ''f''<sub>K</sub> on isomorphism classes of tori over ''K'', as ''K'' runs over finite separable extensions of ''k'', satisfying three properties:
# Multiplicativity: Given two tori ''T''<sub>1</sub> and ''T''<sub>2</sub> over ''K'', ''f''<sub>K</sub>(''T''<sub>1</sub> × ''T''<sub>2</sub>) = ''f''<sub>K</sub>(''T''<sub>1</sub>) ''f''<sub>K</sub>(''T''<sub>2</sub>)
# Restriction: For a finite separable extension ''L''/''K'', ''f''<sub>L</sub> evaluated on an ''L'' torus is equal to ''f''<sub>K</sub> evaluated on its restriction of scalars to ''K''.
# Projective triviality: If ''T'' is a torus over ''K'' whose weight lattice is a projective Galois module, then ''f''<sub>K</sub>(''T'') = 1.

T. Ono showed that the Tamagawa number of a torus over a number field is such an invariant.  Furthermore, he showed that it is a quotient of two cohomological invariants, namely the order of the group <math>H^1(G_k, X^\bullet(T)) \cong Ext^1(T, \mathbb{G}_m)</math> (sometimes mistakenly called the [[Picard group]] of ''T'', although it doesn't classify '''G'''<sub>m</sub> torsors over ''T''), and the order of the [[Tate–Shafarevich group]].

The notion of invariant given above generalizes naturally to tori over arbitrary base schemes, with functions taking values in more general rings.  While the order of the extension group is a general invariant, the other two invariants above do not seem to have interesting analogues outside the realm of fraction fields of one-dimensional domains and their completions.

pages.title: Automorphic form
pages.text:
{{Short description|Generalization of periodic functions to have group domains}}[[Image:Dedekind Eta.jpg|right|thumb|500px|The [[Dedekind eta-function]] is an automorphic form in the complex plane.]]

In [[harmonic analysis]] and [[number theory]], an '''automorphic form''' is a well-behaved function from a [[topological group]] ''G'' to the complex numbers (or complex [[vector space]]) which is invariant under the action of a [[discrete subgroup]] <math>\Gamma \subset G</math> of the topological group. Automorphic forms are a generalization of the idea of [[periodic function]]s in Euclidean space to general topological groups.

[[Modular form]]s are automorphic forms defined over the groups [[SL2(R)|SL(2, '''R''')]] or [[PSL2(R)|PSL(2, '''R''')]] with the discrete subgroup being the [[modular group]], or one of its [[congruence subgroup]]s; in this sense the theory of automorphic forms is an extension of the theory of modular forms. More generally, one can use the [[Adele ring|adelic]] approach as a way of dealing with the whole family of [[congruence subgroup]]s at once. From this point of view, an automorphic form over the group G('''A'''<sub>''F''</sub>), for an algebraic group G and an algebraic number field ''F'',  is a complex-valued function on G('''A'''<sub>''F''</sub>) that is left invariant under G(F) and satisfies certain smoothness and growth conditions.

[[Henri Poincaré|Poincaré]] first discovered automorphic forms as generalizations of [[Trigonometric functions|trigonometric]] and [[elliptic function]]s. Through the [[Langlands conjectures]] automorphic forms play an important role in modern number theory.<ref name=Freidberg2013>{{cite web|last=Friedberg|first=Solomon|title=Automorphic Forms: A Brief Introduction|url=https://icerm.brown.edu/materials/Slides/sp-s13-off_weeks/Automorphic_Forms-_A_Brief_Introduction_]_Solomon_Friedberg,_Boston_College.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606222417/http://icerm.brown.edu/materials/Slides/sp-s13-off_weeks/Automorphic_Forms-_A_Brief_Introduction_%5D_Solomon_Friedberg,_Boston_College.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 June 2013|accessdate=10 February 2014}}</ref>

==Formulation==

An automorphic form is a function ''F'' on ''G'' (with values in some fixed finite-dimensional [[vector space]] ''V'', in the vector-valued case), subject to three kinds of conditions:

# to transform under translation by elements <math>\gamma \in \Gamma </math> according to the given [[factor of automorphy]] ''j'';
# to be an [[eigenfunction]] of certain [[Casimir operator]]s on ''G''; and
# to satisfy a "moderate growth" asymptotic condition a [[height function]].<ref>{{harvs|txt|last=Bump|authorlink=Daniel Bump|year=2002}}</ref>

It is the first of these that makes ''F'' ''automorphic'', that is, satisfy an interesting [[functional equation]] relating ''F''(''g'') with ''F''(γ''g'') for <math>\gamma \in \Gamma </math>. In the vector-valued case the specification can involve a finite-dimensional [[group representation]] ρ acting on the components to 'twist' them. The Casimir operator condition says that some [[Laplacian]]s{{Citation needed|reason=unveriviable and unsufficient citation about the source|date=May 2017}} have ''F'' as eigenfunction; this ensures that ''F'' has excellent analytic properties, but whether it is actually a complex-analytic function depends on the particular case. The third condition is to handle the case where ''G''/Γ is not [[compact space|compact]] but has [[Cusp form|cusp]]s.

The formulation requires the general notion of ''factor of automorphy'' ''j'' for Γ, which is a type of 1-[[Group cohomology#Cochain complexes|cocycle]] in the language of [[group cohomology]]. The values of ''j'' may be complex numbers, or in fact complex square matrices, corresponding to the possibility of vector-valued automorphic forms. The cocycle condition imposed on the factor of automorphy is something that can be routinely checked, when ''j'' is derived from a [[Jacobian matrix]], by means of the [[chain rule]].

==History==
Before this very general setting was proposed (around 1960), there had already been substantial developments of automorphic forms other than modular forms. The case of Γ a [[Fuchsian group]] had already received attention before 1900 (see below). The [[Hilbert modular form]]s (also called Hilbert-Blumenthal forms) were proposed not long after that, though a full theory was long in coming. The [[Siegel modular form]]s, for which ''G'' is a [[symplectic group]], arose naturally from considering [[moduli space]]s and [[theta function]]s. The post-war interest in several complex variables made it natural to pursue the idea of automorphic form in the cases where the forms are indeed complex-analytic. Much work was done, in particular by [[Ilya Piatetski-Shapiro]], in the years around 1960, in creating such a theory. The theory of the [[Selberg trace formula]], as applied by others, showed the considerable depth of the theory. [[Robert Langlands]] showed how (in generality, many particular cases being known) the [[Riemann-Roch theorem]] could be applied to the calculation of dimensions of automorphic forms; this is a kind of ''post hoc'' check on the validity of the notion. He also produced the general theory of [[real analytic Eisenstein series|Eisenstein series]], which corresponds to what in [[spectral theory]] terms would be the 'continuous spectrum' for this problem, leaving the [[cusp form]] or discrete part to investigate. From the point of view of number theory, the cusp forms had been recognised, since [[Srinivasa Ramanujan]], as the heart of the matter.

==Automorphic representations==
{{See also|Cuspidal representation}}
The subsequent notion of an "automorphic representation" has proved of great technical value when dealing with ''G'' an [[algebraic group]], treated as an [[adelic algebraic group]]. It does not completely include the automorphic form idea introduced above, in that the [[Adele ring|adelic]] approach is a way of dealing with the whole family of [[congruence subgroup]]s at once. Inside an ''L''<sup>2</sup> space for a quotient of the adelic form of ''G'', an automorphic representation is a representation that is an infinite [[tensor product]] of representations of [[p-adic group]]s, with specific [[Universal enveloping algebra|enveloping algebra]] representations for the [[infinite prime]](s). One way to express the shift in emphasis is that the [[Hecke operator]]s are here in effect put on the same level as the Casimir operators; which is natural from the point of view of [[functional analysis]]{{Citation needed|reason=unveriviable and unsufficient citation about the source|date=May 2017}}, though not so obviously for the number theory. It is this concept that is basic to the formulation of the [[Langlands philosophy]].

==Poincaré on discovery and his work on automorphic functions==
One of [[Henri Poincaré|Poincaré]]'s first discoveries in mathematics, dating to the 1880s, was automorphic forms. He named them Fuchsian functions, after the mathematician [[Lazarus Fuchs]], because Fuchs was known for being a good teacher and had researched on differential equations and the theory of functions. Poincaré actually developed the concept of these functions as part of his doctoral thesis. Under Poincaré's definition, an automorphic function is one which is analytic in its domain and is invariant under a discrete infinite group of linear fractional transformations. Automorphic functions then generalize both [[Trigonometric functions|trigonometric]] and [[elliptic function]]s.

Poincaré explains how he discovered Fuchsian functions:
:''For fifteen days I strove to prove that there could not be any functions like those I have since called Fuchsian functions. I was then very ignorant; every day I seated myself at my work table, stayed an hour or two, tried a great number of combinations and reached no results. One evening, contrary to my custom, I drank black coffee and could not sleep. Ideas rose in crowds; I felt them collide until pairs interlocked, so to speak, making a stable combination. By the next morning I had established the existence of a class of Fuchsian functions, those which come from the [[hypergeometric series]]; I had only to write out the results, which took but a few hours.''

pages.title: Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula
pages.text:
{{short description|formula in Lie theory}}
In [[mathematics]], the '''Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula''' is the solution for <math>Z</math> to the equation

:<math>e^X e^Y=e^Z</math>
for possibly [[noncommutative]] {{mvar|''X''}} and {{mvar|''Y''}} in the [[Lie algebra]] of a [[Lie group]]. There are various ways of writing the formula, but all ultimately yield an expression for <math>Z</math> in Lie algebraic terms, that is, as a formal series (not necessarily convergent) in <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> and iterated commutators thereof. The first few terms of this series are:
:<math>Z = X+Y+\frac{1}{2}[X,Y]+\frac{1}{12}[X,[X,Y]]-\frac{1}{12}[Y,[X,Y]]+\cdots\,,</math>
where "<math>\cdots</math>" indicates terms involving higher commutators of <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>. If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are sufficiently small elements of the Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak g</math> of a Lie group <math>G</math>, the series is convergent. Meanwhile, every element <math>g</math> sufficiently close to the identity in <math>G</math> can be expressed as <math>g=e^X</math> for a small <math>X</math> in <math>\mathfrak g</math>. Thus, we can say that ''near the identity'' the group multiplication in <math>G</math>—written as <math>e^Xe^Y=e^Z</math>—can be expressed in purely Lie algebraic terms. The Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula can be used to give comparatively simple proofs of deep results in the [[Lie group–Lie algebra correspondence]].

If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are sufficiently small <math>n\times n</math> matrices, then <math>Z</math> can be computed as the logarithm of <math>e^Xe^Y</math>, where the exponentials and the logarithm can be computed as power series. The point of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula is then the highly nonobvious claim that <math>Z:=\log(e^Xe^Y)</math> can be expressed as a series in repeated commutators of <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>. 

Modern expositions of the formula can be found in, among other places, the books of Rossmann<ref>{{harvnb|Rossmann|2002}}</ref> and Hall<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} </ref>.

== History ==
The formula is named after [[Henry Frederick Baker]], [[John Edward Campbell]], and [[Felix Hausdorff]] who stated its qualitative form, i.e. that only [[commutator]]s and commutators of commutators, ad infinitum, are needed to express the solution. An earlier statement of the form was adumbrated  by [[Friedrich Schur]] in 1890 <ref>F. Schur (1890), “Neue Begruendung der Theorie der endlichen Transformationsgruppen,” ''[[Mathematische Annalen]]'', '''35''' (1890), 161–197. [http://www.digizeitschriften.de/dms/img/?PID=GDZPPN002252120 online copy]</ref> where a convergent power series is given, with terms recursively defined.<ref>see, e.g., [[Shlomo Sternberg]], ''[http://www.math.harvard.edu/~shlomo/docs/lie_algebras.pdf Lie Algebras]'' (2004) Harvard University. (''See page 10.'')</ref> This qualitative form is what is used in the most important applications, such as the relatively accessible proofs of the [[Lie correspondence]] and in [[quantum field theory]]. Following Schur, it was noted in print by Campbell<ref>[[John Edward Campbell|J. Campbell]], ''Proc Lond Math Soc'' '''28''' (1897) 381–390; J. Campbell, ''Proc Lond Math Soc'' 29 (1898) 14–32.</ref> (1897); elaborated by [[Henri Poincaré]]<ref>[[Henri Poincaré|H. Poincaré]], ''Compt Rend Acad Sci Paris'' 128 (1899) 1065–1069; ''Camb Philos Trans'' 18 (1899) 220–255.</ref> (1899) and Baker (1902);<ref>[[Henry Frederick Baker|H. Baker]], ''Proc Lond Math Soc'' (1) 34 (1902) 347–360; H. Baker, ''Proc Lond Math Soc'' (1) 35 (1903) 333–374; H. Baker, ''Proc Lond Math Soc'' (Ser 2) 3 (1905) 24–47.</ref> and systematized geometrically, and linked to the [[Jacobi identity]] by Hausdorff (1906).<ref>F. Hausdorff, "Die symbolische Exponentialformel in der Gruppentheorie", Ber Verh Saechs Akad Wiss Leipzig 58 (1906) 19–48.</ref> The first actual explicit formula, with all numerical coefficients, is due to [[Eugene Dynkin]] (1947).<ref>{{harvnb|Rossmann|2002}} p. 23</ref> The history of the formula is described in detail in the article of Achilles and Bonfiglioli<ref>{{harvnb|Achilles|2012}}</ref> and in the book of Bonfiglioli and Fulci<ref>{{harvnb|Bonfiglioli|2012}}</ref>.

== Explicit forms ==
For many purposes, it is only necessary to know that an expansion for <math>Z</math> in terms of iterated commutators of <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> exists; the exact coefficients are often irrelevant. (See, for example, the discussion of the relationship between [[Lie_group–Lie_algebra_correspondence#The_correspondence|Lie group and Lie algebra homomorphisms]] in Section 5.2 of Hall's book<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}}</ref>, where the precise coefficients play no role in the argument.) A remarkably direct existence proof was given by [[Martin Eichler]].<ref>[[Martin Eichler]] (1968).
"A new proof of the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula", ''J. Math. Soc. Japan'' '''20''', 23-25. [http://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.jmsj/1260463291 online] open access.</ref>; see also the "Existence results" section below.

In other cases, one may need detailed information about <math>Z</math> and it is therefore desirable to compute <math>Z</math> as explicitly as possible. Numerous formulas exist; we will describe two of the main ones (Dykin's formula and the integral formula of Poincaré) in this section.

===Dynkin's formula===
Let ''G'' be a Lie group with Lie algebra <math>\mathfrak g</math>. Let
:<math>\exp : \mathfrak g\rightarrow G </math>
be the [[exponential map (Lie theory)|exponential map]].
The following general combinatorial formula was introduced by [[Eugene Dynkin]] (1947),<ref name="Jacobson" /><ref name="dynkin">{{cite journal| last=Dynkin |first=Eugene Borisovich |authorlink=Eugene Dynkin |year=1947 |language=Russian |title=Вычисление коэффициентов в формуле Campbell–Hausdorff |trans-title=Calculation of the coefficients in the Campbell–Hausdorff formula | journal=[[Doklady Akademii Nauk SSSR]] |volume=57 |pages=323–326}}</ref>

: <math>\log(\exp X\exp Y) =
\sum_{n = 1}^\infty\frac {(-1)^{n-1}}{n}
\sum_{\begin{smallmatrix} r_1 + s_1 > 0 \\ \vdots \\ r_n + s_n > 0 \end{smallmatrix}}
\frac{[ X^{r_1} Y^{s_1} X^{r_2} Y^{s_2} \dotsm X^{r_n} Y^{s_n} ]}{(\sum_{j = 1}^n (r_j + s_j)) \cdot \prod_{i = 1}^n r_i! s_i!},
</math>

where the sum is performed over all nonegative values of <math>s_i</math> and <math>r_i</math>, and the following notation has been used:

: <math> [ X^{r_1} Y^{s_1} \dotsm X^{r_n} Y^{s_n} ] = [ \underbrace{X,[X,\dotsm[X}_{r_1} ,[ \underbrace{Y,[Y,\dotsm[Y}_{s_1} ,\,\dotsm\, [ \underbrace{X,[X,\dotsm[X}_{r_n} ,[ \underbrace{Y,[Y,\dotsm Y}_{s_n} ]]\dotsm]].</math>

It should be emphasized that the series is not convergent in general; it is convergent (and the stated formula is valid) for all sufficiently small <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>.
Since {{math|[A, A] {{=}} 0}}, the term is zero if <math>s_n > 1</math> or if <math>s_n = 0</math> and <math>r_n > 1</math>.<ref>A.A. Sagle & R.E. Walde, "Introduction to Lie Groups and Lie Algebras", Academic Press, New York, 1973. {{ISBN|0-12-614550-4}}.</ref>

The first few terms are well-known, with all higher-order terms involving [''X'',''Y''] and [[commutator]] nestings thereof (thus in the [[Lie algebra]]):

{{Equation box 1
|indent =:
|equation = : <math>\begin{align}
Z(X,Y)& =\log(\exp X\exp Y) \\
&{}= X + Y + \frac{1}{2}[X,Y] +
\frac{1}{12}\left ([X,[X,Y]] +[Y,[Y,X]]\right ) \\
&{}\quad
- \frac {1}{24}[Y,[X,[X,Y]]] \\
&{}\quad
- \frac{1}{720}\left([Y,[Y,[Y,[Y,X]]]] + [X,[X,[X,[X,Y]]]] \right)
\\
&{}\quad +\frac{1}{360}\left([X,[Y,[Y,[Y,X]]]] + [Y,[X,[X,[X,Y]]]]\right)\\
&{}\quad
+ \frac{1}{120}\left([Y,[X,[Y,[X,Y]]]] + [X,[Y,[X,[Y,X]]]]\right)
+ \cdots
\end{align}</math>
|cellpadding= 6
|border
|border colour = #0073CF
|background colour=#F9FFF7}}

The above lists all summands of order 5 or lower (i.e. those containing 5 or fewer X's and Y's). Note the ''X'' ↔ ''Y'' (anti-)/symmetry in alternating orders of the expansion, since {{math|''Z''(''Y'', ''X'') {{=}} −''Z''(−''X'',−''Y'')}}. A complete elementary proof of this formula can be found [[Derivative of the exponential map|here]].

===An integral formula===
There are numerous other expressions for <math>Z</math>, many of which are used in the physics literature.<ref name='magnus' /><ref>{{cite journal|author=Suzuki, Masuo| year=1985|title=Decomposition formulas of exponential operators and Lie exponentials with some applications to quantum mechanics and statistical physics|journal=Journal of Mathematical Physics| volume=26| issue=4|pages=601–612 | doi=10.1063/1.526596|bibcode = 1985JMP....26..601S }}; [[Martinus Veltman|Veltman, M]], [[Gerard 't Hooft|'t Hooft, G]] & [[Bernard de Wit|de Wit, B]] (2007), Appendix D.</ref> A popular integral formula is<ref name="miller">W. Miller, ''Symmetry Groups and their Applications'', [[Academic Press]], New York, 1972, pp 159–161. {{ISBN|0-12-497460-0}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Theorem 5.3</ref>
:<math>\log(e^X e^Y) = X + \left ( \int^1_0 \psi \left ( e^{\operatorname{ad} _X} ~ e^{t \,\text{ad} _ Y}\right ) \, dt \right) \, Y, </math>
involving the [[Bernoulli number#Generating function|generating function for the Bernoulli numbers]],
:<math> \psi(x) ~\stackrel{\text{def}}{=} ~ \frac{x \log x}{x-1}= 1- \sum^\infty_{n=1}
{(1-x)^n \over n (n+1)} ~, </math>
utilized by Poincaré and Hausdorff.<ref group="nb">Recall
:<math>\psi(e^y)=\sum_{n=0}^\infty B_n ~ y^n/n! </math> ,
for the [[Bernoulli numbers]], ''B''<sub>0</sub> = 1, ''B''<sub>1</sub> = 1/2, ''B''<sub>2</sub> = 1/6,
''B''<sub>4</sub> = −1/30, ...</ref>

=== Matrix Lie group illustration ===
For a matrix Lie group <math>G \sub \mbox{GL}(n,\mathbb{R})</math> the Lie algebra is the tangent space of the identity ''I'', and the commutator is simply [''X'', ''Y''] = ''XY'' − ''YX''; the exponential map is the [[matrix exponential|standard exponential map of matrices]],

:<math>\exp X = e^X = \sum_{n=0}^\infty {\frac{X^n}{n!}}.</math>

When one solves for ''Z'' in

:<math>e^Z = e^X e^Y,</math>

using the series expansions for {{math|exp}} and {{math|log}} one obtains a simpler formula:
:<math> Z =
\sum_{n>0}
\frac{(-1)^{n-1}}{n}
\sum_{\begin{smallmatrix} r_i+s_i>0\,
 \\ 1\le i\le n\end{smallmatrix}}
\frac{X^{r_1}Y^{s_1}\cdots X^{r_n}Y^{s_n}}{r_1!s_1!\cdots r_n!s_n!}, \quad ||X|| + ||Y|| < \log 2, ||Z|| < \log 2.</math><ref group="nb">{{harvnb|Rossmann|2002}} Equation (2) Section 1.3. For matrix Lie algebras over the fields {{math|'''R'''}} and {{math|'''C'''}}, the convergence criterion is that the log series converges for ''both sides'' of {{math|''e''<sup>''Z''</sup> {{=}} ''e''<sup>''X''</sup>''e''<sup>''Y''</sup>}}. This is guaranteed whenever {{math|{{!}}{{!}}''X''{{!}}{{!}} + {{!}}{{!}}''Y''{{!}}{{!}} < log 2, {{!}}{{!}}''Z''{{!}}{{!}} < log 2}} in the [[Hilbert–Schmidt norm]]. Convergence may occur on a larger domain. See {{harvnb|Rossmann|2002}} p. 24.</ref>
The first, second, third, and fourth order terms are:
* <math>z_1 = X + Y</math>
* <math>z_2 = \frac{1}{2} (XY - YX)</math>
* <math>z_3 = \frac{1}{12} (X^2Y + XY^2 - 2XYX + Y^2X + YX^2 - 2YXY)</math>
* <math>z_4 = \frac{1}{24} (X^2Y^2 - 2XYXY - Y^2X^2 + 2YXYX).</math>

It should be emphasized that the formulas for the various <math>z_j</math>'s is ''not'' the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula. Rather, the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula is one of various expressions for <math>z_j</math>'s ''in terms of repeated commutators of <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>''. The point is that it is far from obvious that it is possible to express each <math>z_j</math> in terms of commutators. (The reader is invited, for example, to verify by direct computation that <math>z_3</math> is expressible as a linear combination of the two nontrivial third-order commutators of <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>, namely <math>[X,[X,Y]]</math> and <math>[Y,[X,Y]]</math>.) The general result that each <math>z_j</math> is expressible as a combination of commutators was shown in a elegant, recursive way by Eichler <ref>[[Martin Eichler]] (1968).
"A new proof of the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula", ''J. Math. Soc. Japan'' '''20''', 23-25. [http://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.jmsj/1260463291 online] open access.</ref>. 

A consequence of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula is the following result about the [[trace (linear algebra)|trace]]:
:<math>\operatorname{tr} \log (e^X e^Y)= \operatorname{tr} X + \operatorname{tr}  Y.   </math>
That is to say, since each <math>z_j</math> with <math>j\geq 2</math> is expressible as a linear combination of commutators, the trace of each such terms is zero.

=== Questions of convergence ===
Suppose <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are the following matrices in the Lie algebra <math>\operatorname{sl}(2;\mathbb C)</math> (the space of <math>2\times 2</math> matrices with trace zero):
:<math>X=\begin{pmatrix}0&-\pi\\ \pi&0\end{pmatrix};\quad Y=\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\ 0&0\end{pmatrix}</math>.
Then
:<math>e^X e^Y = \begin{pmatrix}-1&0\\ 0&-1\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}1&1\\ 0&1\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix}-1&-1\\ 0&-1\end{pmatrix}.</math>
It is then not hard to show<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Example 3.41</ref> that there does not exist a matrix <math>Z</math> in <math>\operatorname{sl}(2;\mathbb C)</math> with <math>e^X e^Y=e^Z</math>. (Similar examples may be found in the article of Wei<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wei|first=James |date=October 1963 |title=Note on the Global Validity of the Baker-Hausdorff and Magnus Theorems. |journal=Journal of Mathematical Physics  |volume=4 |issue= 10|pages=1337–1341|bibcode = 1963JMP.....4.1337W |doi = 10.1063/1.1703910 }}</ref>.)

This simple example illustrates an important point: The various versions of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula, which give expressions for ''Z'' in terms of iterated Lie-brackets of ''X'' and ''Y'', describe ''formal'' power series whose convergence is not guaranteed. Thus, if one wants ''Z'' to be an actual element of the Lie algebra containing ''X'' and ''Y'' (as opposed to a formal power series), one has to assume that ''X'' and ''Y'' are small. Thus, the conclusion that the product operation on a Lie group is determined by the Lie algebra is only a local statement. Indeed, the result cannot be global, because globally one can have nonisomorphic Lie groups with isomorphic Lie algebras.

Concretely, if working with a matrix Lie algebra and <math>\|.\|</math> is a given [[matrix norm|submultiplicative matrix norm]], convergence is guaranteed<ref name="dynkin" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Biagi|first=Stefano|last2=Bonfiglioli|first2=Andrea|last3=Matone|first3=Marco|date=2018|title=On the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff Theorem: non-convergence and prolongation issues|journal=Linear and Multilinear Algebra|language=en|volume=|pages=1–19|doi=10.1080/03081087.2018.1540534|issn=0308-1087|arxiv=1805.10089}}</ref> if

:<math>\|X\|+\|Y\|< \frac{\ln 2} 2.</math>

== Special cases ==
If ''<math>X</math>'' and ''<math>Y</math>'' commute, that is <math>[X,Y]=0</math>, the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula reduces to <math>e^X e^Y = e^{X+Y}</math>. 

A more interesting case assumes that <math>[X,Y]</math> commutes with both <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>, as for the [[Nilpotent group|nilpotent]] [[Heisenberg group]]. Then the formula reduces to its ''first three terms''. 

'''Theorem''':<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Theorem 5.1</ref> If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> commute with their commutator, <math>[X,[X,Y]]=[Y,[X,Y]]=0</math>, then <math>e^X e^Y = e^{X+Y+\frac{1}{2}[X,Y]}</math>.

This is the degenerate case used routinely in [[quantum mechanics]], as illustrated below. In this case, there are no smallness restrictions on <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>. This result is behind the "exponentiated commutation relations" that enter into the [[Stone–von Neumann theorem]]. A simple proof of this identity is given below.

Another useful form of the general formula emphasizes
expansion in terms of ''Y'' and uses the [[adjoint endomorphism|adjoint]] mapping notation <math>ad_X(Y)=[X,Y]</math>:
:<math>\log(\exp X\exp Y) = X + \frac{\operatorname{ad}_X}{1-e^{-\operatorname{ad}_X}} ~ Y + O(Y^2),</math>

which is evident from the integral formula below. (The coefficients of the nested commutators with a single <math>Y</math> are normalized Bernoulli numbers.)

Now assume that the commutator is a multiple of  ''<math>Y</math>'', so that <math>[X,Y]=sY</math>. Then all iterated commutators will be multiples of <math>Y</math>, and no quadratic or higher terms in <math>Y</math> appear. Thus, the <math>O(Y^2)</math> term above vanishes and we obtain:

'''Theorem''':<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Exercise 5.5</ref> If <math>[X,Y]=sY</math>, where <math>s</math> is a complex number with <math>s\neq 2\pi in</math> for all integers <math>n</math>, then we have
:<math>e^X e^Y = \exp\left( X+\frac{s}{1-e^{-s}}Y\right).</math>

Again, in this case there are no smallness restriction on <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>. The restriction on <math>s</math> guarantees that the expression on the right side makes sense. (When <math>s=0</math> we may interpret <math>\lim\nolimits_{s\to 0} s/(1-e^{-s}) = 1</math>.) We also obtain a simple "braiding identity":

:<math>e^{X} e^{Y} = e^{\exp (s)Y} e^{X}~,</math>

which may be written as an adjoint dilation:
:<math>e^{X} e^{Y} e^{-X} = e^{\exp (s) ~Y} ~.</math>

== Existence results ==

If <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are matrices, one can compute <math>Z:=\log(e^X e^Y)</math> using the power series for the exponential and logarithm, with convergence of the series if <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> are sufficiently small. It is natural to collect together all terms where the total degree in <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> equals a fixed number <math>k</math>, giving an expression <math>z_k</math>. (See the section "Matrix Lie group illustration" above for formulas for the first several <math>z_k</math>'s.) A remarkably direct and concise, recursive proof that each <math>z_k</math> is expressible in terms of repeated commutators of <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> was given by [[Martin Eichler]].<ref>[[Martin Eichler]] (1968).
"A new proof of the Baker-Campbell-Hausdorff formula", ''J. Math. Soc. Japan'' '''20''', 23–25. [http://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.jmsj/1260463291 online] open access.</ref>

Alternatively, we can give an existence argument as follows. The Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula implies that if ''X'' and ''Y'' are in some [[Lie algebra]] <math>\mathfrak g,</math> defined over any field of [[characteristic 0]] like <math>\R</math> or <math>\C</math>, then

:<math>Z = \log(\exp(X) \exp(Y)),</math>

can formally be written as an infinite sum of elements of <math>\mathfrak g</math>. [This infinite series may or may not converge, so it need not define an actual element ''Z'' in <math>\mathfrak g</math>.] For many applications, the mere assurance of the existence of this formal expression is sufficient, and an explicit expression for this infinite sum is not needed. This is for instance the case in the [[Representation theory of the Lorentz group#Local existence and uniqueness|Lorentzian]]<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Section 5.7</ref> construction of a Lie group representation from a Lie algebra representation. Existence can be seen as follows.

We consider the ring <math>S = \mathbb{R}[[X,Y]]</math>of all [[non-commuting formal power series]] with real coefficients in the non-commuting variables ''X'' and ''Y''. There is a [[ring homomorphism]] from ''S'' to the [[tensor product]] of ''S'' with ''S'' over '''R''',

:{{math|Δ : ''S''  → ''S''⊗''S''}},
called the [[coalgebra|coproduct]], such that
:{{math|Δ(''X'') {{=}} ''X''⊗1 + 1⊗''X''}}    and     {{math|Δ(''Y'') {{=}} ''Y''⊗1 + 1⊗''Y''}}
(The definition of Δ is extended to the other elements of ''S'' by requiring '''R'''-linearity, multiplicativity and infinite additivity.)

One can then verify the following properties:
* The map exp, defined by its standard Taylor series, is a bijection between the set of elements of ''S'' with constant term 0 and the set of elements of ''S'' with constant term 1; the inverse of exp is log
* {{math|''r'' {{=}} exp(''s'')}} is '''grouplike''' (this means {{math|Δ(''r'') {{=}} ''r'' ⊗ ''r''}}) [[if and only if]] ''s'' is '''primitive''' (this means {{math|Δ(''s'') {{=}} ''s''⊗1 + 1⊗''s''}}).
* The grouplike elements form a [[group (mathematics)|group]] under multiplication.
* The [[primitive element (co-algebra)|primitive elements]] are ''exactly the formal infinite sums of elements of the Lie algebra'' generated by ''X'' and ''Y'', where the Lie bracket is given by the [[commutator]] [''U'',''V'']=''UV''-''VU''. ([[Kurt Otto Friedrichs|Friedrichs]]' theorem<ref name="magnus">{{Cite journal
| last1 = Magnus | first1 = Wilhelm | title = On the exponential solution of differential equations for a linear operator
| doi = 10.1002/cpa.3160070404 | authorlink= Wilhelm Magnus
| journal = [[Communications on Pure and Applied Mathematics]]
| volume = 7 | issue = 4 | pages = 649–673| year = 1954}}</ref><ref name="Jacobson">[[Nathan Jacobson]], ''Lie Algebras'', John Wiley & Sons, 1966.</ref>)

The existence of the Campbell–Baker–Hausdorff formula can now be seen as follows:<ref name="Jacobson" />
The elements ''X'' and ''Y'' are primitive, so <math>\exp(X)</math> and <math>\exp(Y)</math> are grouplike; so their product <math>\exp(X)\exp(Y)</math> is also grouplike; so its logarithm <math>\log(\exp(X)\exp(Y))</math> is primitive; and hence can be written as an infinite sum of elements of the Lie algebra generated by ''X'' and ''Y''.

The [[universal enveloping algebra]] of the [[free Lie algebra]] generated by ''X'' and ''Y'' is isomorphic to the algebra of all [[non-commuting polynomial]]s in ''X'' and ''Y''. In common with all universal enveloping algebras, it has a natural structure of a [[Hopf algebra]], with a coproduct Δ. The ring ''S'' used above is just a completion of this Hopf algebra.

== The [[Hans Zassenhaus | Zassenhaus]] formula ==
A related combinatoric expansion that is useful in dual<ref name="magnus" /> applications is
: <math>e^{t(X+Y)}= e^{tX}~ e^{tY} ~e^{-\frac{t^2}{2} [X,Y]} ~
e^{\frac{t^3}{6}(2[Y,[X,Y]]+ [X,[X,Y]] )} ~
e^{\frac{-t^4}{24}([[[X,Y],X],X] + 3[[[X,Y],X],Y] + 3[[[X,Y],Y],Y]) } \cdots</math>
where the exponents of higher order in ''t'' are likewise nested commutators, i.e., homogeneous Lie polynomials.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Casas | first1 = F. | last2 = Murua | first2 = A. | last3 = Nadinic | first3 = M. | doi = 10.1016/j.cpc.2012.06.006 | title = Efficient computation of the Zassenhaus formula | journal = Computer Physics Communications | volume = 183 | issue = 11 | pages = 2386–2391 | year = 2012 | pmid = | pmc = |arxiv = 1204.0389 |bibcode = 2012CoPhC.183.2386C }}</ref>
These exponents, {{math|''C<sub>n</sub>''}} in {{math|exp(–''tX'') exp(''t''(''X+Y'')) {{=}} Π<sub>''n''</sub> exp(''t<sup>n</sup> C<sub>n</sub>'')}}, follow recursively by application of the above BCH expansion.

As a corollary of this, the [[Lie product formula|Suzuki–Trotter decomposition]] follows.

== An important lemma and its application to a special case of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula ==
===The identity===
Let {{math|''G''}} be a matrix Lie group and {{math|'''g'''}} its corresponding Lie algebra. Let {{math|ad<sub>''X''</sub>}} be the linear operator on {{math|'''g'''}} defined by {{math|ad<sub>''X ''</sub> ''Y'' {{=}} [''X'',''Y''] {{=}} ''XY'' − ''YX''}}  for some fixed {{math| ''X'' ∈ '''g'''}}. (The [[Adjoint representation of a Lie algebra|adjoint endomorphism]] encountered above.) Denote with {{math|Ad<sub>''A''</sub>}} for fixed {{math|''A'' ∈ ''G''}} the linear transformation of {{math|'''g'''}} given by {{math|Ad<sub>''A''</sub>''Y'' {{=}} ''AYA''<sup>−1</sup>}}.

A standard combinatorial lemma which is utilized<ref name="miller" /> in producing the above explicit expansions is given by<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Proposition 3.35</ref>
:<math>\operatorname{Ad}_{e^X} = e^{\operatorname{ad}_X}, </math>
so, explicitly,
:<math>\operatorname{Ad}_{e^X}Y = e^{X}Y e^{-X} = e^{\operatorname{ad} _X} Y =Y+\left[X,Y\right]+\frac{1}{2!}[X,[X,Y]]+\frac{1}{3!}[X,[X,[X,Y]]]+\cdots.</math>

This formula can be proved by evaluation of the derivative with respect to {{math|''s''}} of {{math|''f'' (''s'')''Y'' ≡ ''e''<sup>''sX''</sup> ''Y'' ''e''<sup>−''sX''</sup>}}, solution of the resulting differential equation and evaluation at ''s'' = 1,
:<math>\frac{d}{ds}f(s)Y = \frac{d}{ds} \left (e^{sX}Ye^{-sX} \right )= Xe^{sX}Ye^{-sX} - e^{sX}Ye^{-sX}X = \operatorname{ad}_X (e^{sX}Ye^{-sX})</math>
or
:<math> f'(s) = \operatorname{ad}_Xf(s), \qquad f(0) = 1 \qquad \Longrightarrow \qquad f(s) = e^{s \operatorname{ad}_X}.</math><ref>{{harvnb|Rossmann|2002}} p. 15</ref>

===An application of the identity===
For {{math|[''X,Y'']}} central, i.e., commuting with both {{mvar|X}} and {{mvar|Y}},
:<math>e^{sX} Y e^{-sX} = Y + s [ X, Y ] ~. </math>
Consequently, for {{math|''g(s)'' ≡ e<sup>''sX''</sup> e<sup>''sY''</sup>}}, it follows that
:<math>\frac{dg}{ds}=\Bigl( X+ e^{sX} Y e^{-sX}\Bigr) g(s) =(X+ Y + s [ X, Y ]) ~g(s) ~, </math>
whose solution is
:<math>g(s)= e^{s(X+Y) +\frac{s^2}{2} [ X, Y ] } ~. </math>
Taking <math>s=1</math> gives one of the special cases of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula described above:
:<math>e^X e^Y= e^{X+Y +\frac{1}{2} [ X, Y] } ~. </math>

More generally, for non-central {{math|[''X,Y'']}} , the following braiding identity further follows readily,
: <math>e^{X} e^{Y}= e^{(Y+\left[X,Y\right]+\frac{1}{2!}[X,[X,Y]]+\frac{1}{3!}[X,[X,[X,Y]]]+\cdots)} ~e^X.</math>

== Application in quantum mechanics ==
A special case of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula is useful in [[quantum mechanics]] and especially [[quantum optics]], where ''X'' and ''Y'' are [[Hilbert space]] operators, generating the [[Heisenberg group|Heisenberg Lie algebra]]. Specifically, we note that the position and momentum operators in quantum mechanics, usually denoted <math>X</math> and <math>P</math>, satisfy the canonical commutation relation:
:<math>[X,P]=i\hbar I</math>
where <math>I</math> is the identity operator. It follows that <math>X</math> and <math>P</math> commute with their commutator. Thus, if we ''formally'' applied a special case of the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula (even though <math>X</math> and <math>P</math> are unbounded operators and not matrices), we would conclude that
:<math>e^{iaX}e^{ibP}=e^{i(aX+bP-ab\hbar)}.</math>
This "exponentiated commutation relation" does indeed hold, and forms the basis of the [[Stone–von Neumann theorem]]<ref>{{harvnb|Hall|2015}} Chapter 14</ref>.

A related application is the [[annihilation and creation operators]], {{mvar|''â''}} and {{math|''â''<sup>†</sup>}}. Their commutator {{math|[''â''<sup>†</sup>,''â'']{{=}} −''I''}} is [[Center (group theory)|''central'']], that is, it commutes with both {{mvar|''â''}} and {{math|''â''<sup>†</sup>}}. As indicated above, the expansion then collapses to the semi-trivial degenerate form:
:<math> e^{v\hat{a}^\dagger - v^*\hat{a}} = e^{v\hat{a}^\dagger} e^{-v^*\hat{a}} e^{-|v|^{2}/2} ,</math>
where {{mvar|''v''}} is just a complex number.

This example illustrates the resolution of the [[displacement operator]], {{math|exp(''vâ''<sup>†</sup>−''v<sup>*</sup>â'')}}, into exponentials of annihilation and creation operators and scalars.<ref>[[Leonard Mandel|L. Mandel]], [[Emil Wolf|E. Wolf]] ''Optical Coherence and Quantum Optics'' (Cambridge 1995).</ref>

This degenerate Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula then displays the product of two displacement operators as another displacement operator (up to a phase factor), with the resultant displacement equal to the sum of the two displacements,
:<math> e^{v\hat{a}^\dagger - v^*\hat{a}} e^{u\hat{a}^\dagger - u^*\hat{a}} = e^{(v+u)\hat{a}^\dagger -(v^*+u^*)\hat{a}} e^{(vu^*-uv^*)/2},</math>
since the [[Heisenberg group]] they provide a representation of is [[Nilpotent group|nilpotent]]. The degenerate Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula is frequently used in [[quantum field theory]] as well.<ref>{{harvnb|Greiner|1996}} See pp 27-29 for a detailed proof of the above lemma.</ref>

pages.title: Berry–Robbins problem
Bruhat decomposition
pages.text:
In mathematics, the '''Bruhat decomposition''' (introduced by  [[François Bruhat]] for [[classical group]]s and by [[Claude Chevalley]] in general) ''G'' = ''BWB'' of certain [[algebraic group]]s ''G'' into cells can be regarded as a general expression of the principle of [[Gauss–Jordan elimination]], which generically writes a matrix as a product of an upper triangular and lower triangular matrices—but with exceptional cases. It is related to the [[Schubert cell]] decomposition of Grassmannians: see [[Weyl group]] for this.

More generally, any group with a [[(B, N) pair|(''B'', ''N'') pair]] has a Bruhat decomposition.

==Definitions==
*''G'' is a [[connected space|connected]], [[reductive group|reductive]] [[algebraic group]] over an [[algebraically closed field]].
*''B'' is a [[Borel subgroup]] of ''G''
*''W'' is a [[Weyl group]] of ''G'' corresponding to a maximal torus of ''B''.

The '''Bruhat decomposition''' of ''G'' is the decomposition
:<math>G=BWB =\coprod_{w\in W}BwB</math>
of ''G'' as a disjoint union of [[double coset]]s of ''B'' parameterized by the elements of the Weyl group ''W''. (Note that although ''W'' is not in general a subgroup of ''G'', the coset ''wB'' is still well defined.)

== Examples ==
Let ''G'' be the [[general linear group]] '''GL'''<sub>''n''</sub> of invertible <math>n \times n</math> matrices with entries in some algebraically closed field, which is a reductive group. Then the Weyl group ''W'' is isomorphic to the [[symmetric group]] ''S''<sub>''n''</sub> on ''n'' letters, with [[permutation matrices]] as representatives. In this case, we can take ''B'' to be the subgroup of upper triangular invertible matrices, so Bruhat decomposition says that one can write any invertible matrix ''A'' as a product ''U''<sub>1</sub>''PU''<sub>2</sub> where ''U''<sub>1</sub> and ''U''<sub>2</sub> are upper triangular, and ''P'' is a permutation matrix. Writing this as ''P'' = ''U''<sub>1</sub><sup>−1</sup>''AU''<sub>2</sub><sup>−1</sup>, this says that any invertible matrix can be transformed into a permutation matrix via a series of row and column operations, where we are only allowed to add row ''i'' (resp. column ''i'') to row ''j'' (resp. column ''j'') if ''i'' > ''j'' (resp. ''i'' < ''j''). The row operations correspond to ''U''<sub>1</sub><sup>−1</sup>, and the column operations correspond to ''U''<sub>2</sub><sup>−1</sup>.

The [[special linear group]] '''SL'''<sub>''n''</sub> of invertible <math>n \times n</math> matrices with [[determinant]] 1 is a [[semisimple algebraic group|semisimple group]], and hence reductive. In this case, ''W'' is still isomorphic to the symmetric group ''S''<sub>''n''</sub>. However, the determinant of a permutation matrix is the sign of the permutation, so to represent an odd permutation in '''SL'''<sub>''n''</sub>, we can take one of the nonzero elements to be −1 instead of 1. Here ''B'' is the subgroup of upper triangular matrices with determinant 1, so the interpretation of Bruhat decomposition in this case is similar to the case of '''GL'''<sub>''n''</sub>.

== Geometry ==
The cells in the Bruhat decomposition correspond to the [[Schubert cell]] decomposition of Grassmannians. The dimension of the cells corresponds to the [[length function|length]] of the word ''w'' in the Weyl group. [[Poincaré duality]] constrains the topology of the cell decomposition, and thus the algebra of the Weyl group; for instance, the top dimensional cell is unique (it represents the [[fundamental class]]), and corresponds to the [[longest element of a Coxeter group]].

==Computations==
The number of cells in a given dimension of the Bruhat decomposition are the coefficients of the ''q''-polynomial<ref>[http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/week186.html This Week's Finds in Mathematical Physics, Week 186]</ref> of the associated [[Dynkin diagram]].

==Double Bruhat Cells==

With two opposite Borels one may intersect the Bruhat cells for each of them.
:<math>G=\coprod_{w_1 , w_2\in W} ( Bw_1 B \bigcap B_- w_2 B_- )</math>

==See also==
* [[Lie group decompositions]]
* [[Birkhoff factorization]], a special case of the Bruhat decomposition for affine groups.
* [[Cluster algebra]]

Cartan subgroup
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], a '''Cartan subgroup''' of a [[Lie group]] or [[algebraic group]] ''G'' is one of the subgroups whose [[Lie algebra]]
is a [[Cartan subalgebra]]. The dimension of a Cartan subgroup, and therefore of a Cartan subalgebra, is the '''rank''' of ''G''.

==Conventions==
The [[identity component]] of a subgroup has the same Lie algebra. There is no ''standard'' convention for which one of the subgroups with this property is called ''the'' Cartan subgroup, especially in the case of disconnected groups.

==Definitions==
A '''Cartan subgroup''' of a '''compact connected [[Lie group]]''' is a maximal connected Abelian subgroup (a [[maximal torus]]). Its Lie algebra is a Cartan subalgebra.

For '''disconnected compact Lie groups''' there are several inequivalent definitions of a Cartan subgroup. The most common seems to be the one given by [[David Vogan]], who defines a Cartan subgroup to be the group of elements that normalize a fixed [[maximal torus]] and fix the [[fundamental Weyl chamber]]. This is sometimes called the '''large Cartan subgroup'''. There is also a '''small Cartan subgroup''', defined to be the centralizer of a maximal torus. These Cartan subgroups need not be abelian in general. 

For '''connected algebraic groups''' over an algebraically closed field a '''Cartan subgroup''' is usually defined as the centralizer of a maximal torus. In this case the Cartan subgroups are connected, nilpotent, and are all conjugate.
